comments:
The IDE (F3) displays the following error message:

  "Error restoring editor:
   Unable to restore: <filename>"

The problem is reproducable and occurs under the following
circumstances:

  (1) Open a project and several of its source files
  (2) Close the IDE
  (3) Reopen the IDE
  (4) Close the project

It is possibly the same problem as #18421.

The corresponding .log entry is:

!ENTRY org.eclipse.team.cvs.core 4 372 Jun 17, 2002 09:25:00.121
!MESSAGE Resource /Mail4ME is not open.
!STACK 1
org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.ResourceException: Resource /Mail4ME is not 
open.

!MESSAGE Unable to restore editor - createElement returned null for input 
element factory: org.eclipse.ui.part.FileEditorInputFactory

I can reproduce the error dialog, but I cannot reproduce that stack trace in the 
log.  Do you see that stack trace every time? Do you have steps to reproduce 
this stack trace from a fresh workspace (It must involve team operations).

Moving to Team for further investigation.. it looks like on project close you're 
trying to set session properties... this is not possible because the project has 
already been closed.  You might need to listen for PRE_CLOSE events to flush 
your sync cache.

I was unable to get the displayed error message but did get the taceback so 
these two things may be independant problems. John's assesment is correct in 
that we do not fluch our cache on close.

The fix for the traceback is easy. We were handling a delta but not checking if 
the project was accessible.

reworded title from:
    Message "Error restoring editor" while trying to close a project

I cannot reproduce either the error dialog or the stack trace so it apears to
have been fixed.

I just found the time to upgrade my Eclipse environment to 2.0.2 and 2.1 M3. 
The bug is still there. It also occurs for a fresh 2.1 M3 workspace, and it 
doesn't look like it has anything to do with CVS, since it occurs for non-
shared projects, too.

Additional details I noticed:

(1) Say I have n Java files (1..n) in my open project, and they have been 
opened in this order.

(2) I close Eclipse, then re-open it.

(2) If I then close the project, I get the error message for files 1..n-1 (in 
this order), but not for n.

Maybe it has something to do with even ordering (or even timing, if things are 
done multi-threaded). One gets the impression that the files are closed in 
descending order, and the project itself is already closed after the first file 
has been closed. Maybe that would explain why the rest of the files can't 
access the project itself when they're being closed (just an assumption from 
someone who's never looked at the source, of course).

An up-to-date snipped from the log looks like this:
